EducationalLevels.Teenager: It helps find a domain name using its IP address, doing the opposite of normal DNS lookup.
EducationalLevels.Undergrad: It queries the special reverse DNS zones (in-addr.arpa / ip6.arpa) to fetch the PTR record for a given IP.
EducationalLevels.GradStudent: Uses reverse DNS zones to retrieve domain names from IPs for network diagnostics and security tasks.
EducationalLevels.Professor: Reverse DNS maps IPs to hostnames via PTR records in the in-addr.arpa/ip6.arpa zones. It's essential for spam filtering, diagnostics, and IP reputation.

ProductDescription.Summary: The Reverse DNS product starts with an IP and returns associated domain information using reverse lookup. It complements the DNS lookup approach of mapping names to IPs.

Methodology.Note: IPv4 addresses are iterated monthly; resulting hostnames and metadata are recorded.
Methodology.Coverage: As of Aug 2023, the database includes 1,191,263,499 records.

UseCases.UseCase: Track hardware like routers and servers per IP

Industry.name: Funds
Industry.Application: Track technology usage across IPs (e.g., AWS) over time

Industry.name: Security
Industry.Application: Monitor all devices or clients connected to an IP address

Process.Step: Query Google DNS (8.8.8.8) using dig -x equivalent
Parse DNS response into Question, Name, Type, Target
If type is CNAME, DNAME, or PTR, extract structured fields
Create Elasticsearch records per line of the answer
Process.Note: Trailing dots are preserved for rawness; parsed target fields are cleaned

DNS.Field: Returned by DNS server; equal to Question
Type of DNS record (PTR, CNAME, DNAME)
